Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: I glanced at the clock, my heart pounding. In ten minutes, I needed to be at the courthouse for a hearing that could change my client’s life. My phone buzzed—Mom’s name flashed on the screen. I hesitated, but answered. Her voice trembled as she told me Dad had been quiet all morning, barely eating, and she was worried. I could hear the strain in her words, the silent plea for comfort. As a daughter, I wanted to be there, to ask if everything was okay, to reassure her and check on Dad myself. But as an advocate, I knew I couldn’t be late. The judge had warned us: no delays, no excuses. My client’s future depended on my presence and preparation. I felt torn, guilt pressing on my chest. My parents needed me, but so did my client. I stared at my briefcase, then at the family photo on my desk, caught between two worlds, each demanding more than I could give.
